<h5 style=\"color: rgb(255, 255, 255); >
The purpose of this site is to provide relevant information in regards to the COVID-19 pandemic to the people that live and work in the Henderson community. Please check back often. We will be adding and updating content on a regular basis during this crisis.
Henderson City-Co. GIS and Henderson Office of Emergency Management
\n","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12,"showEditor":false}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#ffffff"},"rowLayout":"box","color":"#000000"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"iframe-card","settings":{"src":"https://kygeonet.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/8e921035c68e4086bfdc0d6096e079fb","height":500,"scrollable":true,"title":"KDPH COVID-19 Dashboard","mobileSrc":"https://kygeonet.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/be6aa027e95e44ff81294fd442d2ff48"}},"width":12}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"

What to do if you are sick
See all steps from the CDC here
","schemaVersion":1}},"width":6,"showEditor":false},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Call your doctor: If you think you have been exposed to COVID-19 and develop a fever and symptoms of respiratory illness, such as cough or difficulty breathing, call your healthcare provider immediately.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":6}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"\n
\n
\n
Stay Home except to get medical care\n
\n \n \n\n
\n
\n
Separate yourself from other people and animals in your home\n
\n \n \n\n
\n
\n
Call ahead before visiting a doctor\n
.\n \n \n\n
\n
\n
Cover your coughs and clean your hands often\n
\n \n \n\n
\n\n","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12,"showEditor":false}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#ffffff"},"rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
\n
Symptoms\n
Reported illnesses have ranged from mild symptoms to severe illness and death for confirmed coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) cases.
The following symptoms may appear 2-14 days after exposure (based on previous MERS-CoV virus incubation periods).
Source- CDC
\n\n","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"image-card","settings":{"src":"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/images/symptoms-cough.jpg","fileSrc":"","cropSrc":"","alt":"Cough with illustration of person wiping their nose","caption":"","captionAlign":"center","hyperlink":"","hyperlinkTabOption":"new","isUrl":true,"isFile":false,"state":"valid","display":{"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"reflow":false}}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"image-card","settings":{"src":"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/images/symptoms-fever.jpg","fileSrc":"","cropSrc":"","alt":"Fever with illustration of man sweating and holding thermometer","caption":"","captionAlign":"center","hyperlink":"","hyperlinkTabOption":"new","isUrl":true,"isFile":false,"state":"valid","display":{"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"reflow":false}}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"image-card","settings":{"src":"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/images/symptoms-shortness-breath.jpg","fileSrc":"","cropSrc":"","alt":"","caption":"","captionAlign":"center","hyperlink":"","hyperlinkTabOption":"new","isUrl":true,"isFile":false,"state":"valid","display":{"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"reflow":false}}},"width":4}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Call your doctor if you develop symptoms and have been in close contact with a person known to have COVID-19, or have recently traveled from an area with widespread/ongoing community spread of COVID-19.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#ffffff"},"color":"#000000","rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
What You Can Do to Prevent Illness\n\n
There is currently no vaccine to prevent coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The best way to prevent illness is to avoid being exposed to this virus.\n\nThe virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person:
Between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet).
Through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes. These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs.
It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.
","schemaVersion":1}},"width":8,"showEditor":false},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Older adults and people who have severe underlying chronic medical conditions like heart or lung disease or diabetes seem to be at higher risk for developing more serious complications from COVID-19 illness.
Please consult with your health care provider about additional steps you may be able to take to protect yourself.
","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Take Steps to Protect Yourself and Others","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Clean your hands often\n\n
\nWash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds especially after you have been in a public place, or after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing. If soap and water are not readily available, use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.\n\n\n","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Avoid close contact
Avoid close contact with people who are sick
Put distance between yourself and other people if COVID-19 is spreading in your community. This is especially important for people who are at higher risk of getting very sick.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Stay home if you're sick
Stay home if you are sick, except to get medical care. Learn what to do if you are sick.\n","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Cover coughs and sneezes
\n
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze or use the inside of your elbow.
Throw used tissues in the trash.
Immediately wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not readily available, clean your hands with a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Wear a facemask if you are sick
If you are sick: You should wear a facemask when you are around other people (e.g., sharing a room or vehicle) and before you enter a healthcare provider’s office. If you are not able to wear a facemask , then you should do your best to cover your coughs and sneezes. Learn what to do if you are sick.
If you are NOT sick: You do not need to wear a facemask unless you are caring for someone who is sick (and they are not able to wear a facemask). Facemasks may be in short supply and they should be saved for caregivers.","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
Clean and disinfect
Clean AND disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily. This includes tables, doorknobs, light switches, countertops, handles, desks, phones, keyboards, toilets, faucets, and sinks.
If surfaces are dirty, clean them: Use detergent or soap and water prior to disinfection.
Complete disinfection guidance can be found here","schemaVersion":1}},"width":4}]}]},{"containment":"fixed","isFooter":false,"style":{"background":{"isFile":false,"isUrl":true,"state":"","display":{},"transparency":0,"position":{"x":"center","y":"center"},"color":"#dedcdc","image":""},"color":"#aN","rowLayout":"box"},"rows":[{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"

\n
Frequently Asked Questions\n
See also the CDC's general COVID-19 Novel Coronavirus FAQ.\n
","schemaVersion":1}},"width":12,"showEditor":false}]},{"cards":[{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"","schemaVersion":1}},"width":2,"showEditor":false},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"
\n\t
\n\t\t\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t
\n\t\t
What is a novel coronavirus?\n\t\t
A novel coronavirus is a new coronavirus that has not been previously identified. The virus causing coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), is not the same as the coronaviruses that commonly circulate among humans and cause mild illness, like the common cold.
A diagnosis with coronavirus 229E, NL63, OC43, or HKU1 is not the same as a COVID-19 diagnosis. Patients with COVID-19 will be evaluated and cared for differently than patients with common coronavirus diagnosis.
\n\t\n\n\n
\n\t
\n\t\t\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t
\n\t\t
What is the source of the virus?\n\t\t
Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses. Some cause illness in people, and others, such as canine and feline coronaviruses, only infect animals. Rarely, animal coronaviruses that infect animals have emerged to infect people and can spread between people. This is suspected to have occurred for the virus that causes COVID-19. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) are two other examples of coronaviruses that originated from animals and then spread to people. More information about the source and spread of COVID-19 is available on the Situation Summary: Source and Spread of the Virus.
\n\t\n\n\n
\n\t
\n\t\t\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t
\n\t\t
Will warm weather stop the outbreak of COVID-19?\n\t\t
It is not yet known whether weather and temperature impact the spread of COVID-19. Some other viruses, like the common cold and flu, spread more during cold weather months but that does not mean it is impossible to become sick with these viruses during other months. At this time, it is not known whether the spread of COVID-19 will decrease when weather becomes warmer. There is much more to learn about the transmissibility, severity, and other features associated with COVID-19 and investigations are ongoing.
\n\t\n\n\n
\n\t
\n\t\t\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t
\n\t\t
What should healthcare professionals and health departments do?\n\t\t
See the FAQ for Healthcare Professionals from the CDC for more information.
\n\t\n\n\n
\n\t
\n\t\t\n\t\t\t\n\t\t\n\t\n\t
\n\t\t
Enter more questions here\n\t\t

\n\t\n\n","schemaVersion":1}},"width":8,"showEditor":false},{"component":{"name":"markdown-card","settings":{"markdown":"","schemaVersion":1}},"width":2,"showEditor":false}]}]}],"header":{"component":{"name":"site-header","settings":{"fullWidth":false,"iframeHeight":"150px","iframeUrl":"","links":[],"logoUrl":"","title":"Henderson, KY Coronavirus Response","markdown":"\n
